title: CEREBRAL ASYMMETRY: NEW DIRECTIONS IN CORRELATES AND ETIOLOGY
descriptions:
The proposed project, "CEREBRAL ASYMMETRY: NEW DIRECTIONS IN CORRELATES AND ETIOLOGY," aims to explore functional cerebral asymmetry through the study of impaired language development by combining genetic and neuropsychological approaches. This project will build upon the Network efficiency hypothesis, focusing on identifying individual differences in patterns of dissociation between language functions in lateralization. By utilizing methods such as behavioral measures, functional transcranial Doppler ultrasound, and functional magnetic resonance imaging, the project aims to investigate the increased risk for language and literacy impairment if different language functions are represented in opposite hemispheres.

Furthermore, the project will utilize simulations from genetic models to explore twin-cotwin similarity in language lateralization. By employing a Double hit genetic model and focusing on individuals with an extra dose of neuroligin caused by an extra sex chromosome, the project aims to uncover how neurodevelopmental abnormalities arise with more than one hit on a functional brain circuit. Additionally, the project will investigate individuals with inconsistent patterns of language laterality by searching for rare genetic mutations and structural rearrangements that may lead to a departure from consistent left hemisphere language. Overall, this project will provide new insights into the correlates and etiology of cerebral asymmetry, with potential implications for understanding language development and impairment.

This innovative and comprehensive project has the potential to significantly advance our knowledge of cerebral asymmetry and its implications for language development.
